The API reference¶

The view functions¶

This module runs the frontend app of iteratec’s Observerhive.

The app implements a simple webservice where the user can either register projects at a Conductor Service, check his or her registrations or turn on and off receiving event messages for the registered projects.

src.activate_user_setup()[source]¶

Set the active flag to True.

The active flag indicates if a user is currently interested in receiving events for the project he has registered for.

src.change_password()[source]¶

Render the form to change password of current user.

The function retrieves the form to change one’s password and renders it. If the current user submitted the form, the function hashes the password and stores it in the users file of the app.

src.check_username()[source]¶

Check if POSTed username does already exist.

Returns:true if username is already in use
src.deactivate_user_setup()[source]¶

Set the active flag to False.

The active flag indicates if a user is currently interested in receiving events for the project he has registered for.

src.delete_account()[source]¶

Delete the account of the given user.

Returns:HTTP response 302 and redirect to home endpoint.
src.deregister_project()[source]¶

Deregister a project at Conductor service if not done already.

The function checks all projects in the users config file and if a project does not have an id already it will try register it at the specified Conductor Service.

src.edit_registrations()[source]¶

Retrieve all registered projects of the current user and show them.

The function retrieves the current users stored configurations and passes them to the corresponding template so that the user can manipulate them if wished.

src.home()[source]¶

Renders the homepage template.

src.login()[source]¶

Render the login page and check login credentials.

The function renders the login form and checks if username does exist and the provided password is correct when the user submits his or her data.

src.logout()[source]¶

Log the current user out.

Calls the logout_user() function of flask_login and redirects to the homepage of this app.

src.register()[source]¶

Render the form to register a new user.

The function renders the registration form and stores its values if the current user submitted the form.

src.register_project()[source]¶

Register a project at Conductor service if not done already.

The function checks all projects in the users config file and if a project does not have an id already it will try register it at the specified Conductor Service.

src.request_loader(request)[source]¶

Callback function for reloading a user from a Flask request.

The function takes the Flask request and returns a user object or None if the user does not exist.

src.return_active_users()[source]¶

Function to get all users which are currently active.

Returns:set of usernames
src.show_registrations()[source]¶

Retrieve all registered projects of the current user and show them.

The function retrieves the current users stored configurations and passes them to the corresponding template.

src.split_registrations(list_of_registrations)[source]¶

Groups registrations at the same service together.

This function generates a nested list of registrations. Registrations in the same sublist are registered at the same conductor service.

Parameters:list_of_registrations (list) – list of dict objects
Returns:nested list of registrations
src.user_loader(username)[source]¶

Callback function for reloading a user from the session.

The function takes the username and returns a user object or None if the user does not exist.

The “myflask” module¶

src.myflask.get_users(cwd, file_name)[source]¶

Get users and their passwords.

Parameters:
  • cwd (str) – current working directory
  • file_name (str) – name of the file containing the credentials
Returns:

dictionary of users and passwords
class src.myflask.FlaskApp(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

This class provides a customized Flask application for the client frontend.

Variables:
  • cwd (str) – current working directory
  • users (dict) – all users currently registered
  • active_users (dict) – users which want to be notified
classmethod add_user_and_password(username, password)[source]¶

Adds credentials for a new user to the users file.

Parameters:
  • username (str) – name the user has chosen for his account
  • password (str) – with which the user can access his account
classmethod delete_config(username)[source]¶

Delete a config file for specified user.

Parameters:username (str) – specifying the user
Returns:None
classmethod delete_user(username)[source]¶

Removes credentials from users file.

Parameters:username (str) – indicates which account credentials to remove
classmethod load_config(username)[source]¶

Loads the config file and returns the list of registrations.

Parameters:username (str) – indicating for which user
Returns:list of dictionaries representing registrations
classmethod rename_user(current_name, new_name, new_password)[source]¶

Changes user credentials as indicated.

Parameters:
  • current_name (str) – current name used by the user
  • new_name (str) – new name to save
  • new_password (str) – new password to save
classmethod save_config(username, data)[source]¶

Write and safe new config file.

Parameters:
  • username (str) – specifying the user
  • data (list) – list containing all registrations to save
Returns:

None

The “config” module¶

This module provides configurations for the Flask app.

Classes and inheritance are used for configuration. The variables are passed through an from_object() call.

class src.config.Config[source]¶

Template class for Flask configuration.

These settings are the default values when in Production mode.

class src.config.DevelopmentConfig[source]¶

Class providing all variables when in Development mode.

class src.config.ProductionConfig[source]¶

Class providing all variables when in Production mode.

class src.config.StagingConfig[source]¶

Class providing all variables when in Staging mode.

class src.config.TestingConfig[source]¶

Class providing all variables when in Testing mode.

The “models” module¶

This module defines the user models which are used in the app.

class src.models.Anonymous[source]¶

Generic class for anonymous user.

Besides the inherited methods and attributes it defines an id attribute which is set to Guest.

class src.models.Project(project_url, event, credentials)[source]¶

Generic class for registered projects.

Variables:
  • project_url (str) – url of the project at the webservice
  • event (str) – type of event to be followed
  • credentials (dict) – other information about the project
class src.models.Registration(registration_id, service, project_name, project_url, event, active=False)[source]¶

Generic class for a registration.

Variables:
  • registration_id (int) – allocated by the conductor server
  • service (str) – address of the conductor service
  • project_name (str) – name chosen by the user for this project
  • project_url (str) – url of the project
  • event (str) – type of event to be followed
  • active (bool) – indicator if user wants to be notified about this
class src.models.RegistrationSerializer[source]¶

This provides supporting functions for the Class Registration

The serialize_registration() converts a dictionary with all information of a single registration into a Registration object. The deserialize_registration() does the opposite.

static deserialize_registration(registration)[source]¶

Turns a Registration object into a python dict.

Parameters:registration – special object
Returns:dictionary containing parameters of the registration
static serialize_registration(registration)[source]¶

Turns a python dict into a Registration object.

Parameters:registration (dict) – containing parameters of the registration
Returns:Registration object
class src.models.User[source]¶

Generic class for authenticated users.

Besides the inherited methods and attributes it defines an active flag to indicate if a user is currently interested in receiving information about new events.

The “forms” module¶

This module contains all forms used by the Observer-Hive frontend.

class src.forms.ChangeCredentialsForm(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

This class defines the form to change an existing users password.

The form provides one entry fields for the current password and two entry fields for new password, the second one being used for verification.

validate()[source]¶

Custom validator to change credentials.

Checks if user provided the correct password currently in use and changes it if user has entered a new password which has been verified by entering it a second time.

Returns:True if all checks have been passed.
class src.forms.LoginForm(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

This class defines the login form.

The form provides two entry fields for the user’s credentials: username and password.

validate()[source]¶

Custom validator for the login form.

Checks if username is known to the app and compares the entered password to the stored one.

Returns:True if all checks have been passed
class src.forms.RegisterForm(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

This class defines part the registration form.

The form provides entry fields for the chosen username and two entry fields for a password, the second one being used for verification.

validate()[source]¶

Custom validator for new user registrations.

Checks if password is at least 4 characters long and verifies the correct entry by comparing it to the second input of password.

Returns:True if all checks have been passed.
src.forms.get_users()[source]¶

Retrieve all users and their passwords.

Returns:dictionary with all users and passwords

The “loggers” module¶

This module provides functions to setup logging for the Flask app.

Depending on how the application is run the configuration of the logging will be set differently. For more information read the docs of the specific function.

src.loggers.setup_gunicorn_logging(app)[source]¶

This is meant to be called if the Flask app is run by Gunicorn.

The logger will set the handlers of the Flask app logger to the Gunicorn logger. The Flask app will have the same log level as the Gunicorn logger.

Parameters:app – the actual Flask app to be logged
Returns:the logger object
src.loggers.setup_logging(log_level='INFO', log_file='info.log')[source]¶

This is meant to be called if the Flask app is run by its own.

It will set up a console log and a produce a log file in the current working directory.

Parameters:
  • log_level – granularity of log messages
  • log_file – file location to write log messages
Returns:

logger object

The “notify” API reference¶

The “settings” module¶

This module defines cross module variables which are used to handle events.

src.notify.settings.active_users = {}¶
Variables:active_users (dict) – dict of users who want to be notified
src.notify.settings.events = set()¶
Variables:events (set) – set of events which have been received
src.notify.settings.revolving = False¶
Variables:revolving (bool) – indicator if events are shown

The “notify” module¶

This module starts the process which handles events from the conductor.

It starts a thread which will iterate through all received events and handles them. Furthermore it imports the customized HTTPRequestHandler for events and runs a simple server.

The “revolver” module¶

This module provides the actual function to show events.

src.notify.revolver.show_messages()[source]¶

Runs an infinite loop which shows all events.

The function gets the dictionary of active users from the customized Flask app and iterates through it. For each user the intersection of followed projects and events to show is made and only these events will be shown.

Returns:None

The “handler” module¶

This module defines a customized HTTPRequestHandler to receive events.

class src.notify.handler.RequestHandler(request, client_address, server)[source]¶

Customized BaseHTTPRequestHandler.

do_GET()[source]¶

Respond to a GET request.

This request type is currently not supported.

do_HEAD()[source]¶

Respond to a HEAD request.

do_POST()[source]¶

Respond to a POST request and add the event to a set.

The “eventhandler” module¶

This module defines classes to handle events.

For every webservice which can be observed there is one class which provides custom functions to notify the user about events.

class src.notify.eventhandler.EventHandler[source]¶

Base class providing a minimal set of functions to handle events.

static do_something()[source]¶

Writes a logging message that event was received.

Returns:True if statements executed properly
static play_music(**kwargs)[source]¶

Plays an alert.

class src.notify.eventhandler.GitEventHandler[source]¶

Class to handle events on Github.

show_icon()[source]¶

Shows Github icon on unicorn hat.

Returns:None
class src.notify.eventhandler.SVNEventHandler[source]¶

Class to handle events on SVN.

show_icon()[source]¶

Shows SVN icon on unicorn hat.

Returns:None
src.notify.eventhandler.handle_event(event, show=False, project_name=None)[source]¶

Handle event as specified by eventhandler object.

The function instantiates an object according to the webservice the event is related to and renders the event.

Parameters:
  • event – with all information about what happened
  • show (bool) – indicator if unicornhat should be used
  • project_name (str) – name the user has chosen for this project
Returns:

None

The “blinker” module¶

The “loggers” module¶

This module provides the configurations to setup logging for the notifier.

src.notify.loggers.setup_logging(log_level='INFO', log_file='info.log')[source]¶

Defines all configurations for logging of the notifier.

It sets up a console log and a produce a log file in the current working directory.

Parameters:
  • log_level – granularity of log messages
  • log_file – file location to write log messages
Returns:

logger object
